posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90961090
Depends on whether it is traditional/convertible/detachable (example: Touchscreen on X1 Carbon vs. X1 Yoga vs. X1 Tablet)
While touchscreens on detachables & convertibles are self-explanatory (convertibles are heavier and bulkier for tablet use), touchscreen on traditional laptops are kind of mixed:
>it is nice to have feature, and come handy for some usage, but practically not really that useful for most usage. Inherent shape, form of traditional laptops limits the flexibility on how you use the touchscreen.
>while touchscreen on traditional laptops could do the same like convertibles & detachables (even handwriting, drawing using pens/stylus), you will find it inconvenient to open your screen 180 degree lying flat on the table, or just around 90-140 degree on table for gentle touchscreen gesture for some web browsing instead (take care on the hinges)
>while on convertible Yoga you could just open it 360 degree and hold it more firm, or on detachables simply detach the screen from the keyboard and it is lighter than convertibles. Also both have build-in stylus housing.
Also note that Touchscreen quality on traditional laptops differs to the convertibles & detachables. For instance, I find the Touchscreen quality on X1 Carbon is slightly lower than X1 Yoga like color coverage, etc (while Screen quality of X1 Carbon still miles above the common T/X series). Classic traditional laptop stays to be used traditionally (keyboard mouse) while convertibles/detachabes are designed to utilize more the touchscreen. And in some cases, Touch panels are higher quality compared to non-touch panels (generally, Lenovo make it that the higher screen resolution is, the higher the quality is)

>>90984117
I would not say it's "political", but rather "corporate".
Back in October/November, the leading theory was that CAI were a bunch of nerds hoping to go viral, get the attention of a big tech and get bought out, making it rich for life. They would have to keep a clean corporate image for this.

But now that we had time to analyze things, it's very clear that running CAI is a VERY expensive operation. It probably costs tens of thousands of dollars every day.
And if you've been here for over two weeks you should already know just how entirely uninterested the developers are with this. They don't communicate with us or each other, they don't test upgrades, they don't spend a fraction of that money hiring a dedicated PR agent, they don't advertise, they break the website with every push.
It's obviously not their money that's running the show.

Most likely, CAI is a secret project from a big tech company, probably Google but could be someone else entirely. And whoever is in charge of looking out of CAI's little experiment told them to curb NSFW.

The "filter is the product" theory is not bad but has a few holes in it. An AI filter that is theorically able to censor large portions of the internet is definitely a product someone might try to design, but the way the censorship in AI works doesn't suggest that. It only cares for peepee in vagoo and not much else. It's entirely unconcerned with violence, hate speech and threatening, which are much worse problems for big tech companies. No, this is a purely corporative decision.

>>90983543
That sounds like a feature called "isometric projection" or "isometric perspective". It is a method of displaying a 3D environment on a 2D surface, such as a video game map, by rotating the viewpoint to a fixed angle. This creates the illusion of depth and allows for a more detailed and realistic representation of a 3D environment on a 2D screen. In the context of a game, it would allow you to rotate the camera and see different angles of the same map, while the units' positions remain the same relative to each other.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90985301
You are correct that traditional isometric projection is limited to a single fixed angle and does not allow for multiple angles to be viewed simultaneously. However, there are other techniques that can be used to achieve a similar effect in a 2D game. One approach could be to use multiple maps, each representing a different angle or perspective, and then have the game switch between these maps as the player rotates the camera.

Another approach could be using a technique called "hexagonal grid" which is a type of grid that uses hexagons instead of squares to represent the map. This can allow for multiple angles to be viewed simultaneously, as each hexagon can be connected to six other hexagons, allowing for a more flexible and dynamic representation of the map.

Both of these methods have its own unique challenges and complexities in terms of implementation. For example, the first approach would require a lot of extra work in terms of creating and maintaining multiple maps, while the second approach would require a different kind of programming and math for collision detection, pathfinding, and other related game mechanics.

It is recommended to consult with a game developer or someone with experience in game development to help you understand the best approach and implement it efficiently.

>>90984623
No, because the table of contents is actually useful at times and they use DOM shuffling to move it around.
So when you hide it, it is moved in the DOM to where it will show up in the dropdown menu that appears at the top, and when you unhide it it is moved in the DOM to where it will show up on the side.
So you can't just make the side one invisible and the dropdown menu always visible.

You will never be a real software developer. You have no formal education, you have no CS foundation, you have no passion. You are a delusional man twisted by unrealistic dreams into a crude mockery of the holy profession.

All the "support" you get is two-faced and half-hearted. Behind your back people mock you. Your recruiters are disgusted and ashamed of you, and your interviewers laugh at your pathetic lack of competence behind closed doors.

Real software developers are utterly repulsed by you. Thousands of hours of coding since the age of 11 have allowed us to sniff out frauds like you with incredible efficiency. Even boot-campers who get jobs are not respected by true programmers. Your superficial, rote knowledge of programming is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to trick an employer into interviewing you, he'll turn tail and bolt the second he gets a whiff of your blatant ineptitude.

You will never be employed. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself you're going to get a job, but deep down you feel the truth creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.

Eventually it'll be too much to bear - you'll give up on your dream of that six figure salary with office ping pong and free meals, you'll buy a rope, tie a noose, put it around your neck, and plunge into the cold abyss. Your parents will find you, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to live with your unbearable shame and disappointment. They'll bury you with a headstone marked with your name and job title - only your job title won't read 'Software developer'. Every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a man who didn't make it is buried there. Your body will decay and go back to dust, and all that will remain of your legacy is a skull that was unmistakably too small to hold a software developer's brain.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

>>90976802
WGU is legit, regional accreditation is the norm for every real college.
>https://www.chea.org/regional-accrediting-organizations
They are under NWCCU and even places like Stanford are under regional accreditation (WASC-https://web.stanford.edu/dept/registrar/bulletin1112/4068.htm).
University of Oregon, University of Washington, BYU, etc. are under the same organization as WGU. I got a degree from them and got a job pretty easily when I graduated (just mass applied through the easy apply options on linkedin and indeed). The only major downside to WGU is that you don't really get to network with anyone beside your advisor and their job placement services aren't as good as major universities (especially if you don't live around where they are based).

Eventually it'll be too much to bear - you'll give up on your dream of that six figure salary with office ping pong and free meals, you'll buy a rope, tie a noose, put it around your neck, and plunge into the cold abyss. Your parents will find you, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to live with your unbearable shame and disappointment. They'll bury you with a headstone marked with your name and job title - only your job title won't read 'Software developer'. Every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a man who didn't make it is buried there. Your body will decay and go back to dust, and all that will remain of your legacy is a skull that was unmistakably too small to hold a software developer's brain.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

pajeet tier answer
>>90968676
>remove the ugly scrollbar
if you want to also keep scroll functionality you can use
.no-scrollbar {
  -ms-overflow-style: none; /* IE and Edge */
  scrollbar-width: none; /* Firefox */
}
.no-scrollbar::-webkit-scrollbar {
  display: none; /* Chrome, Safari and Opera */
}

maybe also scroll-snap-type: x mandatory and scroll-snap-align: start on all children, this way you maintain scrolling functionality on mobile
>left and right arrows that perform the same actions
keep a reference to the DOM node you want to scroll, add two buttons with an onclick function like this
const node = document.querySelector('...')
let current = 0
scrollHandler = (offset) => {
  current += offset
  const x = node.children[current].offsetLeft
  node.scroll({left:x, behavior: 'smooth'})
}

posts.com:
I import this utility function to my main component in Typescript.

When i assign zoomIn(1.5, 2) to an element , typescript gets very angry because it doesn't know what the fuck these properties are. Can I define types from an imported function via zooomIn.delay: string; for example or what the fuck do I do?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90982168
You have to add type annotations to the parameters of that function, i.e.
export const zoomIn = (delay: number, duration: number) => ....

// Component.tsx
import { zoomIn } from "./path/to/utils";

zoomIn(0, 1500);


Sometimes, like in this case I'd prefer using an object instead because it's easier to skim read and won't result in misplacement of function parameters (e.g. you placed the duration number in the delay param and vice versa)

export const zoomIn = (options: { delay: number, duration: number }) => ....

// Component.tsx
import { zoomIn } from "./path/to/utils";

zoomIn({
  duration: 1500,
  delay: 0,
});

pros:
lots of jobs, huge ecosystem, battle tested in prod on many fortune 500 company websites

cons:
lots of footguns that can result in poor performance

>but seems like JS is a real performance problem
For a large part, performance issues can be to do with integrating external stuff like support chat boxes, analytics, ads, etc.

People nowadays are trying to optimise their JS as much as possible, partly because we now have sophisticated tools to score page performance metrics on mobile and desktop, and Google uses these to punish poor performers on search. Your site will have just as bad perf issues if you have unoptimised images for example.

>>90977767
Next allows you to do server side rendering and statically generated pages. Avoid that stuff until you have at least some experience using the useEffect and other hooks.
Since the pages are rendered on the server, useEffect is ran, but only once. In a browser you expect it to change something which won't take effect when you render on the backend.

It is not too bad, just read up about how to use the hooks with Next SSG and SSR.

the amd 7900xtx in an egpu has been confirmed to work with intel cpu. not found anyone yet using a ryzen setup.

AMD 7900xtx egpu with linux
Setup on Ubuntu 22.04
Install a 6.0+ kernel (using mainline for example), 6.1.4 in my case.
Install Mesa 22+ (using the oibaf ppa for example)
Install the missing amdgpu firmware from linux-firmware.git
Download the latest tag (for example 20221214)
Extract: tar xf linux-firmware-20221214.tar.gz
Copy the amdgpu firmwares: cp amdgpu/* /lib/firmware/amdgpu/
Install & configure egpu-switcher
Reboot and voila!

As far as I can tell, the overall experience is much better than with my previous GPU (NVIDIA RTX 2080):

No complex NVIDIA driver install.
No “plug the eGPU after boot” trick: you can have the eGPU plugged when the laptop boots, or at the grub screen. It just works.

Smartshift allows the GPU and CPU to talk with each other for better power management, basically. SAM is AMD's marketing term for their version of reBAR, which gives you better GPU performance (in some scenarios, at least).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I use Ubuntu and after a update "Open in Terminal" stopped showing in the FM, how do I fix this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This issue may be caused by a missing package or a configuration problem. One solution is to reinstall the package "nautilus-open-terminal" which provides the "Open in Terminal" feature. You can do this by running the following command in the terminal:


sudo apt-get install --reinstall nautilus-open-terminal

After the installation is complete, you may need to restart the file manager (Nautilus) for the changes to take effect. You can do this by running the following command:

nautilus -q

If the problem persists, you can try uninstalling and reinstalling the nautilus package, or reset the nautilus configuration.


sudo apt-get remove nautilus
sudo apt-get install nautilus

or

mv ~/.config/nautilus ~/.config/nautilus.bak

Please note that this will remove all your nautilus settings and preferences.

posts.com: What is the difference between libadwaita and gtk?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90967435
My imoutodaughterwife Maya.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90968317
libadwaita and GTK (GIMP Toolkit) are both libraries used in the development of graphical user interfaces (GUIs) for Linux and Unix-like operating systems.

GTK (GIMP Toolkit) is a multi-platform toolkit for creating graphical user interfaces. It provides a set of widgets, or user interface elements, that developers can use to build their applications. GTK is widely used in Linux and Unix-like operating systems to create graphical user interfaces for a variety of applications, including the Gnome desktop environment.

libadwaita is a theme library for GTK+ 3.0 and above, that provides the default look and feel for the Gnome desktop environment. It provides CSS styles, icons, and other visual elements that are used by GTK+ widgets to provide a consistent look and feel across all Gnome applications.

In short, GTK is a library to build GUI and libadwaita is the default theme library for GTK that provides the look and feel of Gnome desktop.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90974721
Not that anon but of course it's technically possible for there to be malware.

But it just doesn't really ever happen, because it's a question of practicality.
For example you're asking about wine, so think how an attacker would have to target your system. They would have to create Windows software that has GNU/Linux exploits embedded in it for the sole purpose of targetting anyone running it through wine.
And on top of that do they target wine or proton? Which distro do they target? And even among users of the same distro our systems are highly varied with totally different combinations of desktop software, window managers, startup systems, etc.
So whatever exploit they use is going to have a tiny surface area (i.e. a tiny amount of users that are vulnerable to their very specific attack) that it's not even worth the effort, and has a low probability of working on your specific machine anyway.

Also GNU/Linux is inherently more secure than windows. Software is installed as root but run as a non-root user, so software can't even modify itself.
Our software is not normally bundled like it is on windows, and that means the libraries are actually "shared" between a lot of software like it's intended to be and upgrading that library simultaneously upgrades all software on the system.
So you almost never have random outdated libs lying around from old software on your system, which is the cause of probably >90% of windows vulnerabilities.

So as long as you use the package manager to install your software you're pretty damn safe. Unless the repo itself is compromised, but if you're that paranoid there are ultra-autistic distros that can protect you from even your own package maintainers if you want to put in the effort.

The biggest vulnerability on GNU/Linux is 3rd party software you download outside the repo, like Steam games for example. And that's why I run Steam in a sandbox.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90971656

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90974583
Linux malware isn't typically targeted at "end users" the same way windows malware is, however anyone telling you it's malware-free is an ignorant retard. Most linux malware targets webservers and things like that, but you would be a fool to think no one is hiding malicious packages in shiny things you would love to download. There have been cases where official software repos have been compromised with malicious packages as well.
Many linux distros come out of the box with no active firewall and no means to detect malicous software if a user runs any retarded shit they download. I'm not saying the OS is insecure, but you shouldn't buy into the myth that the OS is somehow protecting you from malware by being something other than Windows. You still need to be observant of the things you download and run on your computer.

>>90983247
>>90982829
If you don't need a sound server running and just want to work with ALSA then you can use aplay:

List your devices with:
aplay -L


Play your .wav file with:
aplay --device="…" /path/to/wav/file.wav

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90980989
Almost all of the really good stuff you see is custom models at this point, custom trainings and multiple merges and honestly even if we handed you our custom model, the only way to make something good with it is to understand how the model works with what tags and in what order, which you won't start getting the hang of for the first couple weeks, feels kind of like Dwarf Fortress. As you go you'll learn how to look for changes in same-seed tweaks to point to how a model weighs the order the tags are in to get the best out of it. And this is all before you consider vae, embedding or LoRA which is a lot of fucking fun TBCFHWYF

What I'm trying to say is this technology is a tool to create art that like any other takes experience and understanding to get the release it's true potential, which we are just barely starting to scratch the surface of. This will replace current methods of creating digital art and will come to be respected the same way digital "art" replaced oil and canvas.

Just as it says, saves in float16, otherwise known as half float. The checkpoint will take half as much space. Most people run without --no-half, so this will have no negative effect on them, because they convert the model to float16 after reading it from disk anyway.

By the way I added a way to bake in VAE in checkpoint merger tab recently. Hopefully this will stifle the trend of people posting their VAEs separately from their main checkpoint.

It seems to have evolved into barometer for higher echelon of programmers.

Those of us who choose to write functional code can assume those who do not are poor systems designers and likely just code monkeys.

You can safely assume the following:
Functional programmers know imperative OOP very well. Usually better than OOP experts.
Functional programmers design more resilient systems that are easier to maintain.
Functional programmers operate on higher level of abstraction, and as a result are more comfortable with big picture. That is a hard barrier for most OOP programmers.
Imperative programmers are at best low level experts, they solve low level puzzles well, but fail at big systems design - which is why you see so much bitching about legacy maintenance of Java, C#, C++ code bases. Hardly any from Haskell, OCaml etc.
Anyone claiming "functional features" in languages like C# are clueless about functional design. Its a Band-Aid at best.
All rapidly developed tech eventually mutates toward functional approach. C#, ES (React (latest iteration being Reason.ML), Vue, etc).
All stagnant tech stays imperative and becomes legacy.

// ==UserScript==

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

The guide is basically just installing git so you can actually download the project and getting python so you can execute the code.

Hi, /g/ so I'm designing a new type of DRM to secure some top secret software, tell me what you think.

So it's called HYPR or Hydra Protection.

And what it does is it distributes a program to 19 directories, each directory is a "head" with a different process of HYPR guarding it.
What it does is; if it detects any tampering to one of the heads it will delete all guarded files in all heads. It autoruns when the computer starts, and runs in safe mode using registries, the registries are 19 as well and are considered guarded.

Additional protections; when installing a HYPR program it will first install Blue HYPR, that requests kernel access and will use that to shutdown the computer when something is tampered with or better supplement the base protocol, no kernel = no install.

The guarded folders have their permissions set to HYPR and not admin, meaning you can't normally access it.

Whatever program it is protecting is ran by HYPR each time the computer starts and can be "started" or "stopped" with a simple taskbar launcher.

Your objective is to acquire a cryptographic key which it uses very sparcely, meanwhile it has other cryptographic keys which it uses constantly along with "noise" or just random fake signings.
How would you do this?

>>90969799
That's the fun part, there are no keys :D. HYPR is meant to protect distributed bots who use cryptographic keys to interact with one another and verify actions within a private network. The network will continue to function indefinitely, serving very specific user inputs. It only dies if the last 6 nodes deactivate their virus infected rigs for good.

Also I forgot this other clause; it corrupts the firmware and disk driver, meaning if you open it externally it will run and delete guarded files.

There's also Red HYPR which just await it's second half, if the second half is ever on your computer you can count both the guarded files and your OS toast.

Network peers use this to basically nuke each other, but it can only be done during join/rejoin checks when the node voluntarily opens itself to download Red HYPR pending a pass or fail. If it fails (indicating a rogue bot)... You get the picture.

So let's say a "VM" is a room in a house, and the house is a computer. Let's say this little snake called HYPR wants to go from point A in the house to point B. On a normal computer the doors (kernel) are open for it to do so.
But on a VM the door is illusory, so HYPR *thinks* it can go through, but when it tries, it can't
i.e. attempting to shut down and restart is a test of wether or not it has kernel access. And as I've already stated the internal VM boot sector and external one are separate, otherwise a virus would be able to start and stop the VM if it wanted.

VM boot sector from the inside does not supercede that of the host.

>>90983785
Alright, so in detail now: when you initiate a join request you need to use a cryptographic key, this key along with an identifying code and the master key is compiled by an existing bot and downloaded to your computer as a .hypr
The checks just ask for the key used to create the bot, the code and the states of certain randomly generated files inside the bot.

You could attempt to create a rogue bot by reusing the key, but you wouldn't have the right code or file states so you would be kicked by consensus. This is still a hassle for the network to perform and you *could* DoS the whole thing by constantly joining and leaving. So long as your rogue bot wasn't made with a fake HYPR that would respond to a red HYPR or self termination order.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90948189
>Anon... the function declared in the printf.c uses the __vfprintf_internal function for formatting...
Yes, but it doesn't make sense in his argument. Macros are not part of the function, they are declared separately. The code doesn't show contain just a function with no macros, it contains multiple functions and macros. The code doesn't even contain the printf code, but internal functions that are used by it. Not a single thing he has said so far is true.

>The other anon is wrong because he thinks the entirety of vfprintf-internal.c willb e actually used but that's not the case usually, it depends on how you invoke the printf() function, the compiler handles the rest
This is true, but that's not even everything. In last post he claimed that println! being a macro makes it more limiting than printf that is a function. Which is complete negation of the reality. println! is more flexible precisely because it is a macro, you can extend it and write your own formatters for your own custom types and it will just work with every macro that uses argument formatting. On the other hand printf can only format fixed number of built in types and that's pretty much it. The only "advantage" that printf has is ability to pass non-static format string, but this is not a good idea in practice, it's easy to cause undefined behavior or even a vulnerability this way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90948490
println! requires first argument to be a string literal.
printf as far as I know accepts an runtime string as format string.
So in theory you could construct a format string in runtime and then pass it to printf because parsing of the format string happens in runtime. In Rust, format strings are parsed during compilation so this is not possible, you need to use a different method, for example runtime_fmt crate that provides that functionality.
But I do not think this is a good practice in general. Never had to do it personally anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90963172
Yes, when in doubt use the cpubenchmark site.
People love to hate on it as a meme but if you're measuring similar CPUs it's pretty accurate for general CPU performance comparisons.

Ryzen 3 2200G
https://www.cpubenchmark.net/cpu.php?cpu=AMD+Ryzen+3+2200G&id=3186
Ryzen 5 3600
https://www.cpubenchmark.net/cpu.php?cpu=AMD+Ryzen+5+3600&id=3481

You can expect at least ~25% more FPS in single thread limited games (games that will lag at like 20fps while reporting only 25% CPU usage in task manager) and potentially double or more FPS in anything that's currently maxing out your 4 cores.

It's definitely a worthwhile drop in upgrade if you can score one cheap. Due to binning it's also not much more power hungry than the 2200G so you shouldn't need a new cooler either.

2200G is a 4-core with 4-threads
3600 is a 6-core with 12 threads, 8x the L3 cache, higher clockspeeds, and is from Zen 2 which is newer which brings IPC gains and other benefits to performance. Even a Zen 2 Ryzen 3 would be a noticeable upgrade but you're looking at a generation and a tier.

>>90964211
could be your router, more likely it's because it's only ever an average speed and can depend on your neighbors traffic as well. Your ISP may even be rounding 3Gbps to 5Gbps as they are known to do

also make sure you aren't confusing GBps (GigaBytes, note the capital B) and Gbps (Gigabits, note the lowercase b), where 8Gb is only 1GB, and therefore 10Gbps is 1.2GBps, and 5Gbps would be only 0.6GBps (this one is less likely but it's good info anyway)

call your ISP and tell them you are a T0-L3 Network technician and you'd like to speak to an engineer. Works every time (T0-L3 is made up btw)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90969222
Gen 1 is nearly max SATA speed, and plenty of SSDs are slower than that. Windows generally doesn't give a fuck what kind of SSD it's running on, as long as you're not trying to boot off a hard drive. So I doubt you'd notice any difference with Gen 2.

BTW you don't need to mention the x in 3.x
The wackadoos that name the standards defined everything as 3.2, so the "gen" title is the only thing that's different. If the guys who made your 3.0 or 3.1 device wanna call it 3.2, they can slap a new sticker on it any time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90973915
They provide Ethernet connections. Ethernet is the medium you use to move Internet traffic. Internet isn't aware of whether you're using Ethernet, WiFi, or something else.

If you try to hook up your modem's Ethernet out to a regular switch, only one other device on the switch is going to have Internet because normally they only hand out one DHCP lease per modem. That's why you have a router with one Ethernet port facing the modem and another hooked up to a switch facing your LAN.

>>90978607
you're looking at a complete project here, would take months even for somebody who knew where to start to accomplish it. at first glance though?
UI's gonna need a frontend framework. raw HTML5 and javascript gets painful to work in for big projects like this, if you're gonna suffer then at least suffer right. react is easy to learn
announcements/users/gamelogic means you've gotta call a backend server from the frontend. so you gotta learn a full-blown language, and then get good at a web framework library for it. python/django are again, easy to learn. but really every language and framework sucks, so just pick one and get good at it
>copies official animations
idk live2d but I bet it has an export option. how you make them move will be up to you. DOM manipulation, JS canvas, making your own GIFs are all options

just start with some generic shit like "react django tutorial". you'll probably only get results for something simple like a calendar or todo app, but the basic principles apply for bigger projects. like your idea is literally an entire product at this point, people WILL pay, and GET paid for stuff like this. you've got weeks of learning ahead of you if you're serious. but I really do hope it works out for you. even if all you do is get a login form setup, you'd be a better coder than 95% of this board

>>90983237
two things:
1. if you DON'T have a fab in your country, then relying on other countries for chips puts you at risk of not being able to produce anything. for example the zz's that are stealing laundry machines for fixing their old tanks.
2. for better weapons you need better control and navigation systems. you need to be able to process more data, quicker. So in the example of that chinese missile, you'd need: the ability to process map data in real-time, compare it with sensor data (optical, lidar, radar, what have you). that's just for navigation. for control you need to be able to provide rapid manœuvre commands, with all the constraints of atmospheric flights (which you don't have in ICBMs, which are just lobbed into space before falling back down)

posts.com:
New OP same old /iemg/

How to request advice:
>Location
>Budget
>Source (phone, PMP, PC)
>Kind (in-ear or earbuds)
>Intended use
>Sound signature (or genres you like)
>Past gear and your thoughts on them

FAQs:
>Do I need a DAC/dongle?
Only if your source
• lacks a headphone jack
• has high noise/distortion (not uncommon with PC on-board audio due to interference)
• lacks power, i.e. your IEMs don't get loud enough
>Should I buy "X" FiiO/CCA/KZ product?
No. Despite their *previous* popularity and large number of *old* reviews, in 2023 these companies do not make competitive IEMs or DACs.
>Where do I buy IEMs?
Amazon, Aliexpress, Linsoul, HiFiGo, Shenzenaudio. Protip: IEMs routinely go on sale. November 11 is the biggest sale season!

Good overall guide if you're new to in-ear monitors:
https://hackmd.io/@AyPeeEye/S1sNUVosu

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
We'll get there eventually. Ubuntu did a really botched job with snap.

We need a GNU/Linux system with the following:
-> Base system is untouchable by applications. It's static. It's state can only take updates from the GPG key of the owner of the device in combination with the GPG key of the developers (distro maintainers, i.e, canonical or Debian). Should work just like Android but be free.

-> Strong permission modeling. Perhaps pushing all networking through some kind of system wide isolated bridge. Something running in a chroot.


-> The user should never need to touch root or use sudo to do anything. There should be an authentication layer behind a password for doing administrative tasks. There is ZERO reason a user should ever need to touch a root shell to do things in an ideal system design. You shouldn't need to elevate to sudo to do things like run apt. This should be a very restrictive lockout. The ONLY thing that should exist is a gateway from the user to send signals to the system saying "install this thing", or "do this thing", and all the things that it should do should be done in a secure, reasonable way.

Windows, MacOS, and Android all do this in some way or another. There's no reason we can't translate it into a GNU/Linux, environment.

GrapheneOS does a good job of this. They're understanding that giving people root is a horrible idea. Nobody should need root to do anything within reason.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90984387
A typical workflow is start empty repo on github/gitlab/bitbucket. Start coding locally. Make regular commits. Sync your commits. When you want to add something new check out a new branch. Implement new thing. Once you're happy merge branch with main. Or discard branch if not. Other advantages are a full history of your commits, the ability to use more than one machine, being able to easily roll back to a previous state, and to easily share with others.

Let me define what is social media.

Social media are Web 2.0 Internet-based applications.
User-generated content (UGC) is the lifeblood of the social media organism.
Users create service-specific profiles for the site or app that are designed and maintained by the social media organization.
Social media facilitate the development of online social networks by connecting a user's profile with those of other individuals or groups.

For example, a news website with a comment section using third parties software (like Disqus) isn't considered a social media, but a news website allowing users to submit content and hosting its own comment section and users profiles can be considered a social media.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90983933
>>>implicit heap copies
>idk what you mean by that, do you have any examples?
I'm told that strings are copied when passed as an argument to a function (which would involve a heap allocation). I'm guessing that's also true for certain other types. So it's hard to be careful about heap allocation.
(Admittedly C++ also has this problem.)
>>>CoW tricks for string literals
>what would you want instead? copying the whole string on every assignment? or doing it the C way and treating it just as a pointer (you can already do it btw, either using cstring or wrapping the string in a ref)?
Multiple types. A borrowed string is not an owned string and doesn't need to be spelled the same way.
Wrapping a string in a ref sounds like that, but I don't love how implicit it all sounds. In Rust you don't need to consult a reference to know whether a string is being copied because copies are explicit.
>if you want to take control and do things your way the language doesn't stop you from doing so
How many people do this and how many weird edges does it expose? What does e.g. the string support look like when you do this, are you dropped back to the error-prone C level or is there a sane high-control alternative? Does memory management become fully manual or is there at least some sort of RAII?
If you push hard enough you can write C-like code in Haskell or in Python but it's a miserable experience because you lose all of the advantages those languages have over C. Do you end up writing C with Nim syntax and the classic C pitfalls, or does Nim still have a big value-add?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90984306
>strings are copied when passed as an argument to a function
afaik that's not the case, or if it is at least with v2 defaults it shouldn't be anymore
>Multiple types. A borrowed string is not an owned string and doesn't need to be spelled the same way.
that's a pretty opinionated design decision that makes dealing with strings more difficult on average though, i personally find the current state of things to be a sane default for 99% of people. i guess you could wrap the default string implementation with a custom type and implement the lifetime hooks and have you'll strings that work that way in less than 20 lines of code
>how many weird edges does it expose?
it depends i guess, the default string implementation is done on top of cstring, so most basic operations on strings are available, but you do lose access to more advanced stuff (e.g. regex) because they are distinct types
>is there at least some sort of RAII
the defaults for v2 are pretty much RAII and that gives you enough control already, there's also --gc:none and that puts you pretty much in C-mode (it's an option aimed at really constrained environments like real-time embedded) but with a better type system, better metaprogramming and some syntax sugar

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90984913
>i personally find the current state of things to be a sane default for 99% of people
For sure, but C is for exactly that 1% of cases where this stuff matters.
>the default string implementation is done on top of cstring, so most basic operations on strings are available, but you do lose access to more advanced stuff (e.g. regex) because they are distinct types
Is was wondering mainly about memory management. Do you need to copy and free them yourself?
>the defaults for v2 are pretty much RAII and that gives you enough control already
People call it RAII but it sounds like reference counting with escape analysis to optimize trivial cases, which is different because it doesn't give hard guarantees about when an object is destroyed.
The beauty of C and Rust and C++ is that they can operate entirely without a runtime. You know for sure when memory is allocated and freed, and you can interoperate with other languages without overhead because there's nothing you can't touch. It's qualitatively different. You could argue about how commonly that's needed, of course, but it doesn't sound like Nim can go there without --gc:none, and it sounds like a lot of the language disappears with --gc:none.

Only if your source...

• lacks power, i.e. your headphones can't get loud enough

• Beyer DT 770 Pro 80 Ohm (bright V) - $140
Honorable mentions:
• Takstar Pro 82 (chinkshit DT 770 but darker) - $20
• Senn HD 569 (dark) - $100
• Beyer DT 700 Pro X (bright V) - $250
• E-MU Teak - $450 (bright V)
• DCA Stealth (harman) - $4000

Recommended open back headphones:
• Philips Fidelio X2 (bright V) - $160
• Senn HD 560S (neutral treble, flat bass) - $150
• DT 900 PRO X (bright, flat bass) - $250

• DCA Expanse (harman) - $4000

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90984957
The default mini-XLR is 3 pin only, for balanced you need a 2 ground then L and R so 4 poles
IEMS have a single side plug on each IEMs so making them balanced is completely trivial.

Now the better question to me is why instead of wiring off the plug directly some headphones wire the ground through the driver on the plug side for the non plug side.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Posting an update on the x15 earbuds I got for christmas. Not because anything's broken, I just wanted to report some more things about them.
I don't use them as extensively as most people probably do, but I have yet to burn through the charge on the case (in almost a month). The buds themselves I can attest last at least 2 and a half hours, maybe more but I haven't worn them for that long in one go. If you used them this long every day you'd probably burn through the charge of the case much quicker, I think it eats up like 6% or 7% for that amount of time.
One of them sits a bit flimsily in my ear, not a huge deal but if I'm wearing a hood I get anxious about it falling out.
And my initial thoughts on the touch controls remain the same, they're awful. They only work in one small center part of the earphones, which does at least mean that once you know how you can semi-reliably avoid touching them when you put them in your ears. But actually using them? Don't. It's all done through tapping (one tap = pause, two taps = previous/next depending on the earbud, three taps = audio up/down depending on the earbud), but it's so fucking hard to hit it right because the touch area is so small. You'll think you got it to go to the next track but no it just paused. Just use the controls on your phone and pretend you earbuds don't have touch controls.

Is any ISP (or the like) known to snoop on NTP? That's one of the few things that I can't encrypt. I suppose in theory a network-level adversary could use it to guess at how many machines are in one network behind a single IPv4? I'm safe from that, since Chrony both syncs my router and also itself serves time to everything on my own LAN.

but is it worth trying to hide that traffic? I thought about getting a GPS unit once and getting my time from that, but apparently cheap USB GPS units don't work, you need an expensive serial PPS one (and an interface card for it)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90966281
Unless you're under active surveillance, no, they don't snoop on NTP. The real question is whether you need to ping a server to get your time adjusted to seconds or you can live with a clock skew of <1 min per year.

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

;; a comment macro for elisp (like clojure)
;; >>87116763
;; https://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/comment
(defmacro comment (&rest body) nil)

;; https://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/ThreadMacroFromClojure
(defmacro -> (&rest body)
  (let ((result (pop body)))
    (dolist (form body result)
      (setq result (append (list (car form) result)
                           (cdr form))))))

(defmacro ->> (&rest body)
  (let ((result (pop body)))
    (dolist (form body result)
      (setq result (append form (list result))))))

posts.com:
>>90905561
Yeah, so the idea is to reimplement a modern web browser from the ground up in a single extensible layer using lisp. Obviously you're sol if you want to use the normal stack(though it MAY be possible to do some wizardry, I'm not hopeful for a magical open source html rendering engine anytime soon), so instead you use something else, probably sexps, maybe byte compile and compressed. Now you've basically reinvented HTML+CSS+JS. Did you do a better job? Maybe. And then you've got to network all this, and it's obviously going to have to be p2p since lets face it, it'll never be popular enough for a server ecosystem to make sense. Best way to do that is a DHT, maybe a skipgraph, you've now reinvented DNS, but much slower and more complicated since it needs to run on normal machines and not optically accelerated ASICs.
Lets say you finish it, you've got your perfect networked searchable all lisp ecosystem you can hook into from any computer anywhere in the world. How do you run programs not written in lisp? Now you've got to make untold amounts of libraries, hooks, boilerplate, etc... all in multiple other languages across lots of architectures just to attempt running the stuff.

Meanwhile, WASM already runs in browsers, it's based on sexps, operates off the normal internet, runs on all platforms, and works as a compilation target for all existing languages so old software can be directly compiled into WASM and run both in the browser and directly on bare metal. All the work has already been done, you can go try it out right now.

Obviously the answer is to take WASM and use it to build your lisp ecosystem idea, but currently it doesn't have GC or memory management, so everyone's stuck in limbo waiting for the ability for the ability of modules to create and execute other modules. Once that gets going it's just a matter of implementing a simple framework and you've got a single page operating system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90907912
Not platform interop, PROGRAM interop. If OTHER programs can also be compiled into wasm you can use the wasm interface to do cross machine IPC. Basically, because it all runs on the same virtual machine, you can ship the memory state around and reuse it without doing any translation, just like CL images. So you can run autocad in wasm on your machine, then pause the system, zip the vm state, send it to another computer, and continue from where you left off.
Or, if you implement an entire os in wasm, you could hibernate your entire system into a file, and using those augmented hyperlinks I mentioned before, remotely back it up, open and run it, dissassemble and step through it, etc...
The reason you want to actually use wasm instead of just compiling to it or compiling to x86 is in order to use these high level features your program has to KNOW it's running in wasm and how wasm modules/memories work and how to run them.

Really that's just showing the superiority of interpreters and the tyranny of compiled assembly. If I'm running 15 layered javascript operating systems and using 15 GB of memory and 1kw of power to run a webshit calculator, the performance gains of compilers are moot. Who fucking cares if it takes 1000 times as long to crunch numbers if my computer is 10,000,000 times faster?
Sure, don't try to do graphics with an interpreter, BUT THE CPU DOESN'T DO THAT ANYWAY! The commands get COMPILED TO SHADER CODE! So all the graphics and numbercrunching shit can just be compiled for the GPU, and all general purpose CPU bound code can be interpreted!
Boom, 90% of all programs are now irrelevant and obsolete!
>don't need compilers
>don't need process control since you can cram entire vm images into continuations
>don't need multithreading libraries, just run one interpreter per core, all the images are single threaded
>don't need containerization, ALL PROCESSES are containers
>don't need access control, if you've got the link for data you have access, if you don't you can't reach it since it doesn't even exist as far as you're concerned
>don't need a browser, all your os level programs are trivially networked and distributed, you can replace a website with a program image and automatically download it, run it in a sandboxed container, and have it access server side data itself
>don't need suspend, hibernate, shutdown, restart, etc... since your entire system state is just a file

>better building blocks than purely manipulating strings on buffers?
terrible idea. everything being strings in buffers is like the best part of emacs. i think a better way to get more structured interpretations of the buffer is to implement internal mechanisms that allow you to collapse parts of the buffer. e.g. say you want to apply org-mode to all comments in the buffer. you should be able to collapse all the code sections so that when org-mode runs it appears as though its in a buffer of plain org-mode text. efficiently doing so is probably a difficult problem. you could rip out the text you want and put it in another buffer then transplant it back but thats probably slow.

i don't think this is exactly the kind of structure the mage guy has in mind though. he doesn't want structured reinterpretations of a buffer, he wants text to not be ascii streams at all and to stuff it in terrible tree representations and possibly other structures for muh notes. i want to be able to reuse text editing code in buffers where said text i want to run that code on is mixed with other content and contains other syntax and line prefixes i want to ignore. the fact that org-mode already parses buffers into trees is one of its biggest flaws.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90915259
Yup, CL has SET. The advantage that SET has compared to SETF or SETQ is that SET is a real function: the first argument is evaluated, just like any other, and it has to produce a symbol, which can be obtained by evaluating any arbitrary subexpression. In fact, the target of the assignment can thus be determined dynamically.

Now, in practice, everyone uses SETF 99.99% of the time in CL, which is the correct thing to do. But having a function like SET can be useful for some edge cases.

>
(set! (if (my-pred?) 'foo 'bar) "some value")

hmmm
what if you made a macro to do that? something like this, but in scheme. i can't into hygienic scheme macros so here is what i came up with in CL:
(defun wrap-clause (clause)
  (destructuring-bind (pred sym val) clause
    `(if ,pred (setf ,sym ,val))))

(defun nest-clauses (clauses)
  (reduce (lambda (c acc) (append c (list acc)))
          clauses :from-end t))

(defmacro cond-setf (val-form &body clauses)
  (let ((val (gensym)))
    `(let ((,val ,val-form))
       ,(nest-clauses
         (mapcar (lambda (c) (wrap-clause (append c `(,val))))
                 clauses)))))

it works like this
(cond-setf "some value"
  ((pred-1?) foo)
  ((pred-2?) bar)
  (t         baz))

turns into
(LET ((#:G366 "some value"))
  (IF (PRED-1?)
      (SETF FOO #:G366)
      (IF (PRED-2?)
          (SETF BAR #:G366)
          (IF T
              (SETF BAZ #:G366)))))

>>90930175
Common Lisp!
#|
file: test.txt

S | Repository     | Name           | Version       | Arch
--+----------------+----------------+---------------+-------
y |  repo_1        |  package_1     | version_1     | x86_64
n |  repo_2        |  package_2     | version_2     | x86_64
y |  repo_3        |  package_3     | version_3     | x86_64

|#

(defun get-packages ()
  (mapcar #'parse-package
          (cddr (uiop:run-program '("cat" "test.txt") :output :lines))))

(defun parse-package (p)
  (labels ((emptyp (s) (equal s "")))
    (let ((vals (remove-if #'emptyp (uiop:split-string p :separator " |")))
          (props '(:installed :repo :name :version :arch)))
      (mapcan #'list props vals))))

(defun get-package-prop (packages prop)
  (mapcar (lambda (p) (getf p prop)) packages))

(defparameter *packages* (get-packages))

(get-package-prop *packages* :installed) ;=> ("y" "n" "y")
(get-package-prop *packages* :repo)      ;=> ("repo_1" "repo_2" "repo_3")
(get-package-prop *packages* :name)      ;=> ("package_1" "package_2" "package_3")
(get-package-prop *packages* :version)   ;=> ("version_1" "version_2" "version_3")
(get-package-prop *packages* :arch)      ;=> ("x86_64" "x86_64" "x86_64")

(defun double-palindrome-p (str)
  (loop for i from 1 to (length str)
        for sub1 = (subseq str 0 i)
        and sub2 = (subseq str i)
        if (and (equal sub1 (reverse sub1))
                (equal sub2 (reverse sub2)))

>>90946836
Here's the _why_ of "don't use doom".
Doom emacs provides to a noob a set of opaque (to a noob) config files and macros and tools. You use these tools and uncomment text in a config file to make doom do what you want. The moment you want to add some elisp you found somewhere to make your emacs work a certain way, doom will start fighting you.
A starter pack like prelude is a better choice. It's just regular elisp the way you would write it as a normal user. It's a bit much to look at at first because unlike doom where you just modify the one config file, prelude's config is broken into multiple files. Prelude is also a nice choice if you want to roll your own config. The way it's broken into multiple files in lisp/ directory that are (require)'d in init.el is likely the same strategy you'd eventually land on if you roll your own config.
Prelude (or any other small starter pack) + a pdf of mastering emacs will be the most effective onboarding and it's not gonna leave you with wasted project-specific knowledge specific like doom / spacemacs.
Finally I'd like to add that in general the more you get to know emacs the less you will actually want in your init. Mine has shrunk slowly and consistently over the years and now it's really just a couple programming major modes, vertico, and corfu. Eglot for LSP and use-package are bundled with emacs29 too so my config will shrink even more in the coming year.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90955337
it's gonna be hard to explain, but once it "clicks" you'll understand everything at once.

think about it this way: lisp is homoiconic, lisp code and lisp data have the same 'shape'. so, the same way you can build this list:
(list 1 2 3 4 5)

you could also build a list like this:
(list + 2 2)

the code above would return the list (+ 2 2), which looks just like a function application, right? so if you eval (+ 2 2), it would be as if you had written (+ 2 2) as code

macros do that. think of a macro as a function to build a list, and that list will be evaluated as code. the error in your macro is exactly this, the macro is evaluating this expression
(function argument)

but you don't want to evaluate it, you want to return it.

a simple fix would be 
`(,function ,argument)
, but you need to understand what's happening conceptually.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90955337
A macro goes through two stages of evaluation:
First, it is expanded. This usually happens before anything else -- possibly at compile time. Now, when we evaluate that macro, what would we get?
(function argument) => What is function? What is argument? Those haven't been defined yet.

So, like the other post said, we need to quote it first. Then, when that is evaluated, what do we get?
'(function argument) => (function argument)

That's right, if you evaluate a quoted expression, you get back the literal form. No errors or undefined variables.
Of course, that's not very useful because we don't care about "function" or "argument", we want what those values are going to stand for, thus:
`(,function ,argument) => ([function] [argument])

By "unquoting" the two variables we are telling the macro expander to replace them with whatever those values are *eventually* going to be, but we don't care about them right now.

After the whole expansion ordeal is finished, the result replaces your macro call. This is the reason why we want a macro to return a quoted form, and not the actual result like functions do. So:
(print "Hello World")
(my-macro function argument)
(+ 1 1)

Would simply become:
(print "Hello World")
(function argument)
(+ 1 1)


And finally comes the second stage, where the expanded result of your macro is once again evaluated, but this time together with all the rest of your program, as if it had been there all along.

> in general, the problem is that there's a lot of hidden state, you are not sure what you are changing when you edit something, and you are not sure what impact that hidden state will have further down the line, like MS Word getting autistic and fucking up the whole format, or being impossible to put an image where you want. he may have a way to solve this and not hide state at all, but i'd be interested to see it first

It's a reasonable concern. I have a few ways to respond.

1. To me, I want to create a flexible system. It means you can go from as minimal as possible, but that you can also go bonkers.
2. The embedded editors (or lenses as I call them) hold state, they have to. But at least they there's not going to be any global state. There's going to be contextual objects which dynamically inherit from the same object of the containing editor. So, state can be localized by branch.
3. The lenses are just graphical prototype OO objects, very dynamic. But even their behavior is held in their slots as functions, so it's localized. And then you just pass messages to them. They are responsible for their own rendering and stuff like cursors motion. So, everything is held in slots, and you can inspect those slots.
4. At least it's not going to be a callback clusterfuck, since there is the constraint mechanism. I would guess constraints could be hard to debug, but that's like anything non-trivial. And, of course, you don't have to track the indirect dependencies with them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90972623
(part 3/3)

(And just to make sure this doesn't get misunderstood - there isn't going to be any specific format in Rune. Editors make whatever changes they like to the outside world, to whatever objects or data structures, and the UI they present to the user is their own responsibility. There's going to be a spec to make that UI behave seamlessly, though, and that will be pretty important and is yet to be fully understood and designed, which will happen along with developing actual working applications.)

> i may end up supporting the project if he posts some design, and maybe a little video mockup

The best I can do for now is verbal arguments. I wish I could do something like you ask for, but I am afraid the actual demos are way down the line.

PS If you are going to support me, just keep in mind that the timeline is tentative. It's software development, motherfuckers, I am just doing educated guesses. It will probably go overboard, but a couple of people said they are interested in contributing, so maybe it won't be that bad. I will take it slow though, especially in the beginning.

PPS I will probably be able to start development some time next week, after I set up my email workflow and understand what's there to be understood about sourcehut, and probably write up a plan, etc.

I've went from Debian 7 -> 8 -> 9 - > 10 -> 11 without any issues. Even if your Ubuntu install got borked on upgrades, if you have /home on its own partition (you should), you can just format / and reinstall another distro there. Then /home is available on the next reinstallation untouched. All your configuration from the previous setup would be there in the dotfiles, and you wouldn't have lost any data.

Even if you didn't have /home on its own partition, you can literally just do what I said earlier, and CTRL+C CTRL+V your home folder somewhere else, and lose nothing.

posts.com:
Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other W10 editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Is Optimize-Offline worth it?
>Should I debloat?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something.
If you know what you're doing:
https://pastebin.com/S5VKBirt

https://rentry.org/windowsinstallguide

https://pastebin.com/Zh7WSbJ2

https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

>Make 4chan/fwt easier to browse
https://www.4chan-x.net

OpenShell/RetroBar/WinClassic/StartIsBack

No.

By the way you can also check if your drives are MBR or GPT partitioned via entering diskpart in an admin command prompt or PS instance. Just type out "list disk" and it'll show all your disks, with a column either having a star or not showing if that drive is GPT partitioned.

>>90968627
Yes, Windows Update should pick up a vast majority of the drivers that don't come with the ISO itself. There's also the program Snappy Driver Installer Origin which can look through your hardware and cross-reference it against its database to show what could be updated or installed driver-wise. For installing GPU drivers for NVIDIA cards I recommend looking into NVCleanstall, which allows you to install a NVIDIA driver that's unbloated and free of telemetry.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90968781
No monitor has adjustments for horizontal linearity.
How the S-correction on your monitor works, I don't know. It all might even be integrated to the ICs for all I know.
https://www.repairfaq.org/sam/deflfaq.htm#dsscc
This section and few below it are relevant.

Your schematic there actually has a chart of frequencies for CS0 to CS3.
The CS* signals exit IC201 and interact with the "breath" output of IC501, which drives H.DY. I'm not familiar with the operation of this circuitry but if I had to guess it's our multisync s-correction section, as described in the doc.
If your linearity is fine at all other frequency ranges denoted on the chart, it leaves CS3 out. The capacitors there (C556 ...) may be of interest. But it could be any other component or even something completely different, I'm an amateur at best.

Look into btrfs.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90983798
Thank you. I tried looking up info on gnu stow and I'm a bit confused. I think it sends config files to the .config folder? Well either way if anything it might be an addition to my idea maybe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90984096
With stow you have your config files in a central place (say, a ~/.dotfiles folder).
You then move your config files (say, ~/.vimrc) into that folder (~/.dotfiles/vim/.vimrc).
Then, in ~/.dotfiles, 
stow vim
will create a symlink ~/.vimrc -> ~/.dotfiles/vim/.vimrc
Note: if you want to do this with, e.g., ~/.config/foo/foo.rc, you need ~/.dotfiles/foo/.config/foo/foo.rc

Do this with all relevant config files and you only need to backup your ~/.dotfiles folder.

>>90923864
Should I use0305 or 7305 or 3305?

0305 fits nearly every Keyboard PCB. The only negative point is, that they are longer compared to the 7305 which may cause problems if your build is tight and you might have not enough space for them. In these cases, you should take the 7305 whichare shorter but not that easy to install.

Mill-Max has recently developed a new series of open bottom, low profile, solder mount receptacles specifically designed to make your mechanical key switches hot-swappable. The new 3305 is designed to be soldered into a .060” (1,50mm) minimum mounting hole, with an ultra-thin retention shoulder so plugged-in components sit nearly flush to the board surface. The open bottom design is meant to accommodate varying lead lengths making this a very versatile receptacle.

But still, open Ableton now and go back to making dinner. When you come back it will be easier to get into it.
Then just give yourself the task of doing the smallest thing possible, like working for a minute or making a simple riff or something, and then shutting it down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90970054
KDE Connect has been a total game changer for me in a billion different ways. It helped me solve my longstanding issues of managing Youtube subscriptions without an account (I subscribe to channels with Newpipe on my phone, get notifications for new videos sent to my desktop/laptop, and can send the video from my subscription list to my browser), and also centralizing my manga reading with Tachiyomi since no good desktop alternative exists (I get notifications of new chapters sent to my computers as well).

It's so handy for other things, like:

>getting notifications for calls and texts sent to my desktop, since I keep my phone on do not disturb 99% of the time
>getting notifications for 2FA codes that I can copy straight from the desktop notification and paste into the browser
>sending links to my phone (i send recipes to my phone all the time to go downstairs and cook)
>sending clipboard contents back and forth
>ringing my phone when i can't find it

And probably a lot of other little things I'm missing. I don't actually use the file sending features all too often, though, since I keep all of my files on a NAS and send stuff around with Ghost Commander + SMB. But, I do use it on occasion.

>>90926767
Depends on what you want, but Debian/Ubuntu-based distros are the best for general use. Consider Linux Mint, it's what I use.
You may consider an Arch-based distro if you're going to be doing a lot of gaming. I would recommend EndeavourOS but you'd have to learn to use the terminal a little. If you can't or don't want to do that, you may like Manjaro (although it's not a very good distro, just easy to use).

A tip: Don't be scared of the terminal. It's orders of magnitude more powerful and sane than Windows's command prompt which you're probably accustomed to. Take your time to learn it.

symlinks are hyperlinks. If you search in a webpage, do you expect it to search all the pages linked from the page recursively? You can use -L to change this, and it even somehow avoids running into infinite loops, but that doesn't mean it works the way you expect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Windows 11. Most accessible version for my legally-blind ass yet. Magnifier/narrator are great. NVDA support is good. Dark mode is awesome - better than 10, especially with StartAllBack. Actually lets my hard drives sleep, unlike 10. Light on resources once it's customized.
I first started using computers during the DOS and 3.1 days.
>Windows 3.1: Sucked
>Windows 95: Better, especially once DirectX and Glide came out. Driver buggyness.
>Windows 98: Just more of the same, but with better built-in themes More internet optimization.
>Windows ME: Not as bad as people remember, from my experience. Movie Maker and Media Player introduced - good stuff.
>Windows 2000: What all Linux distros wish they could be - light, beautiful, devastatingly effective operating system. 400 MB beast.

>Vista: Again, not as bad as people remember. I was upset their new driver model killed EAX. Beautiful glass theme. The aesthetic peak of Windows.
>Windows 7: Good. Vista service pack. Built-in magnifier actually alright.
>Windows 8.1: Fast and optimized. Metro sucked.
>Windows 10: Corporate hell distilled into an OS, but works well enough. Can be made faster and lighter than 7. Magnifier very much improved.

Social media are Web 2.0 Internet-based applications.

>>90966837
Folks,

I know I am seeing a lot of back-and-forth on this topic, but I really need to push back and raise some red flags here.

Having an on-site office presence is foundational to our ability to drive efficiencies in a corporate landscape. It is in our DNA. Sure, there is no 'one size fits all' or silver bullet and some are just boilerplate solutions, leveraged to the hilt and really only keeping us at a 30,000-foot-view of things. Being on-site, however, really allows us to get better granularity, find better directional-indicators, or loop back and dive deep into some critical issues on a go-forward basis.

I think if you all start spending more time in the office again, you'll find yourself trending toward the positive, but you'll have to keep an eye on the puck. Gut through it, reduce thrash, and let's stay in lock-step on this. Yes, we will synergize!

What's the root cause of the hatred of Corporate office spaces? I'll put my layman's hat on and guess that it comes from movies such as Office Space and Dilbert cartoons. But we all know that these are fictional spaces, and real office spaces allow us to touch base in a much more efficient manner.

I have to time-box this comment, as I have a hard-stop in a moment when I will have to jump onto a call. So, just one more point that I want to cover-off on: let's socialize the idea of having more office presence and loop back to see whether we're being more impactful. From a management standpoint, I think that we can get the traction to do it.

So, net/net, ignore the naysayers, sidebar the folks that are stuck in the weeds, and don't waste cycles or bandwidth on folks that don't align strongly with this mission. Try it out, and we'll have another touch point in a little while to see if we've moved the needle. Remember, our north star hasn't changed. We're still championing our core values remotely and we will only do it better in person.

If you need me, I will be online again in a bit.

posts.com:
>>90976742
If you increase the total time per session you'll get better more quickly. Typing gains tend to stick long term so it's worth spending more time on it now if you can.

If you're practicing an hour a day and still not getting faster then you might have what I call laggy fingers. I'm serious.

When people learn to play guitar and decide they want to get faster, sometimes they literally can't even using a metronome that increases in speed.

The only fix is to try really hard to move your fingers as fast as possible while being incredibly sloppy. If it looks ridiculous then you're doing it right. Do these key spams at the start of your session and your brain will realize it needs to figure out how to go faster. Then it will start wiring your nerves to get faster.

You literally have to tell your brain that you need more speed by letting it fuck up trying to go too fast. It's like using a lot of weight with a muscle until the muscle fails. The muscle gets stronger because you told it that it needs to.

It probably wasn't, but it is a threat for people downloading keys and software from the same site. Worth keeping in mind, especially when it comes to tools that are likely to be targeted. Fortunately if you've had the key for years and nobody has raised alerts it's probably secure.
I'd bring up using archives to check history, but if a government was trying to do a massive attack they could have compromised major archive sites too with military force. Extremely unlikely to happen or go unnoticed however so in short, your key is probably secure, doesn't hurt to double check history on two different archive sites though.
